<@U0CLC803W|jamesvanhallen> has joined the channel

would like somebody to confirm this weird behavior with Shared Element Transition, fragmentA to fragmentB (v4). All I want to know is when transition is over. So I just put a listener in fragmentB like this: `(Transition) getSharedElementEnterTransition().addListener()` which is never called. But! If I also add an empty listener to the same transition in fragmentA, then both listeners start working ¯\_(ツ)_/¯. Here is the simple demo: <https://github.com/Ghedeon/TransitionBug>

attachments.title: Ghedeon/TransitionBug
attachments.text: Contribute to TransitionBug development by creating an account on GitHub.

but yes, that was the trick with changeBounds. It does work only when I put that empty listener
so weird `getSharedElementEnterTransition()` gets called when going back. Not on entering
I want to listen when enter of FragmentB is finished
but does it work for you with this empty listener hack?
nope
`getSharedElementEnterTransition()` listens to exit :joy:

guys, how do you usually provide Glide RequestManager to custom views?

when I use picasso I used to have Picasso instance in Dagger and just injected it in the target class. but Glide request manager should be attached to the fragment/activity to handle lifecycle events. So the method is not suitable
The issue I made regarding my problem: <https://github.com/JakeWharton/ThreeTenABP/issues/42>

attachments.title: Handle Click Button in recycler view
attachments.text: I have recycler view with OnItemTouchListener and each row this recycler has a button with onclick event.I want after click button event work but OnItemTouchListener work.please help. my code.
attachments.fallback: Handle Click Button in recycler view

text: hello. what do you guys use for remote device testing?
<@U2CJ7PGSF> do you want to keep the touch listener? The link you provided looks legit to me, `holder.itemView.setOnClickListener()` is a straightforward way of doing this
Yea, I want to keep the touch listener, but the button listener should overrule the touch listener, so not both events are triggered
It just seems really unnecesary to create both a new interface and touch listener instead of using generic listeners for the purpose
In this case, it would mean I would have to create a new interface and touch listener class for each new click event I want
or what ui-testing frameworks do you recommend?

<@U2CJ7PGSF> I'm wondering what are you trying to achieve with that touch listener in a first place, so you want to keep it. If it's all about item clicks - setOnClickListener() is clear and less hackish solution. If you need that touch listener for some other complex juggling with touch events then idk.
I have already set an onClickListener on the view in the adapter, but the problem is that the event from the button onClickListener and the view item Touch Listener are both activated
When clicking the button, the touch listener event should be ignored
You probably should override the onInterceptTouchEvent and then call requestDisallowInterceptTouchEvent or something.
